comments:
Business Economics and Public Policy 250 (previously named BPUB 250) introduces students to "managerial economics," the application of microeconomic theory to management problems. Microeconomic theory is a highly useful set of ideas for understanding and analyzing human behavior in a variety of contexts. The goal in this course is to help students understand this body of theory so they can analyze private and public management problems in an economic framework. This is a "tools" course, but the course will discuss many business applications and offer a strong emphasis on prescription, as opposed to description. For example, the course will focus on profit maximization as a management objective rather than simply a foregone conclusion. The term begins with a brief introduction of the theory of supply and demand underlying the competitive market model, the benchmark for evaluating other market structures similar to those encountered by real-world firms including monopoly, oligopoly, and monopolistic competition. The course will then move to build an understanding of the development and use of market power, and strategic interaction among firms. Last, the course will examine market failures including asymmetric information and externalities.

Overall, this course was described as useful with “a lot of substantial materials.” This course covered materials on intermediate microeconomics and had some overlaps with ECON 10. Students learned to apply mathematical tools such as derivatives to solve relevant economics problems. Many students said the lectures and recitations were very useful and thought-provoking. However, students hoped that the more difficult math-related concepts were taught by the instructor instead of teaching assistants. 

Students described Professor Kessler as “nice” and “accessible.” Many said that he was great at communicating the subject matter and “engag[ing] student interest.” Professor Kessler taught in a straightforward manner and at an acceptable pace. However, many students complaint that the lectures slides were simply “reflection of textbook” and that Professor Kessler often tended to read off the slides.

There were complaints on the grade distribution of this course. Specifically, some students said that the exams were “worth too much,” and there seemed no need to assign 10% of the grade to class participation while problem sets were only worth 5%.All Wharton students are required to take this course or ECON 101. The prerequisites of this course are ECON 1 or equivalent, and MATH 103 or equivalent.

BPUB 250 introduces students to "managerial economics," the application of microeconomic theory to management problems. Microeconomic theory is a remarkably useful body of ideas for understanding and analyzing human behavior in a variety of contexts. The goal of the course is to get students to internalize this body of theory well enough so that they can analyze management problems. While it is a "tools course," the class is mindful of applied business problems. After presenting the competitive model, the class dwells on other market structures more like those encountered by typical firms (monopoly, oligopoly, monopolistic competition). It spends some time on microeconomic lessons on the development and use of market power, as well as strategic interaction among firms. Finally, it spends some time on the theory of market failure.
Students were fairly neutral about the course material.  A few described the course as “great.”  However, a number of students also felt that the material itself was “pretty dull,” and those who enjoyed the class felt that the professor’s teaching style as opposed to the course material is what made the class worthwhile.  
Most students thought Professor Duggan was “phenomenal.”  Several praised him for being “very knowledgeable about the material” and “[going] out of his way to link the course to real world situation[s].”  Additionally, a number of students noted that “he was funny, witty, [and] engaging.” Others praised Professor Duggan for being “very accessible.”  One student appreciatively noted that Professor Duggan listened to student “comments about the class and, [as a result], made more of an effort to focus on example problems.” 
The midterms and final were weighted heavily, and a few students felt these exams were difficult.  Students were also graded on problem sets but only on completion.  The prerequisites are ECON 1 or equivalent and MATH 103 or equivalent.  BPUB 250 is part of the Wharton core.

This course introduces students to "managerial economics," the application of microeconomic theory to management problems. Microeconomic theory is a remarkably useful body of ideas for understanding and analyzing human behavior in a variety of contexts. The goal in this course is to internalize this body of theory well enough to analyze management problems. While this is a "tools course", the course will be mindful of applied business problems throughout the semester. After presenting the competitive model the course will dwell on other market structures more like those encountered by typical firms (monopoly, oligopoly, monopolistic competition). The course will spend some time on microeconomic lessons on the development and use of market power, as well as strategic interaction among firms. Finally, the course will spend some time on the theory of market failure.

	Students were strongly dissatisfied with the material since they said it was “non-stimulating basic economics” and “not an interesting course.” One student even said it was “a waste of time.”

	Students also complained about Professor Miravette. They said that Professor Miravette was “boring” and “unhelpful.” 

	Some complained about the mandatory attendance and participation. The prerequisites included: ECON 001, AP credit or the equivalent; MATH 103, AP credit or the equivalent. This class is now listed as BEPP 250.

BPUB 250 introduces students to "managerial economics," the application of microeconomic theory to management problems. Microeconomic theory is a highly useful set of ideas for understanding and analyzing human behavior in a variety of contexts. Our goal in this course is to help you understand this body of theory so you can analyze private and public management problems in an economic framework. This is a "tools" course, but we will discuss many business applications and offer a strong emphasis on prescription, as opposed to description. For example, we will focus on profit maximization as a management objective rather than simply a foregone conclusion. The term begins with a brief introduction of the theory of supply and demand underlying the competitive market model, the benchmark for evaluating other market structures similar to those encountered by real-world firms including monopoly, oligopoly, and monopolistic competition. We then move to build an understanding of the development and use of market power, and strategic interaction among firms. Last, we examine market failures including asymmetric information and externalities. 
Students described the course as a “difficult” course that was made easier by the teaching of Professor Duggan. The course covered “a lot of good concepts.” One student felt that the textbook wasn’t essential to the learning of the course and mentioned that the class heavily emphasized “problems” in order to do well in the course.
Reviews for Professor Duggan were largely positive. “Amazing to have for BPUB 250,” Professor Duggan was “engaging,” “patient,” and “extremely well qualified.” One student pointed out that Professor Duggan occasionally “cold called students.” Regarding accessibility, students agreed that Professor Duggan made a strong effort to be accessible to his students by “holding extra office hours” and “explaining things again and again” until students fully understand a topic.
BPUB 250, now BEPP 250, is a required course for all Wharton undergraduates.

BPUB 250 introduces students to "managerial economics," the application of microeconomic theory to management problems. Microeconomic theory is a highly useful set of ideas for understanding and analyzing human behavior in a variety of contexts. Our goal in this course is to help you understand this body of theory so you can analyze private and public management problems in an economic framework. This is a "tools" course, but we will discuss many business applications and offer a strong emphasis on prescription, as opposed to description. For example, we will focus on profit maximization as a management objective rather than simply a foregone conclusion. The term begins with a brief introduction of the theory of supply and demand underlying the competitive market model, the benchmark for evaluating other market structures similar to those encountered by real-world firms including monopoly, oligopoly, and monopolistic competition. We then move to build an understanding of the development and use of market power, and strategic interaction among firms. Last, we examine market failures including asymmetric information and externalities. 
Students found the class was “packed with information” that was useful and interesting. It “definitely takes what was learned in introductory economics and expands upon it.” A few students mentioned the class was less mathematical and less “rigorous” than expected and felt the class could have made better use of the calculus that students are learning as a prerequisite to make the course “much more applicable.”
Reviews for Professor Gelber were mostly positive. Professor Gelber “seemed like he was very invested in the course and conveying the material.” A few students mentioned that they “really enjoyed having Professor Gelber.” Some students felt that the participation required in the course was unnecessary, and one student mentioned that Professor Gelber’s efforts to engage the class, while endearing, was “not the best way to teach a class that was rooted in math.”
BPUB 250, now BEPP 250, is a required course for all Wharton undergraduates.
